meanings.meaning: to water an animal, imbibe, drink up, fill with liquid, saturate
to shrink (fullers shrinking their cloth in water)
to feed (enable metal to enter the mold in metal casting)
burnt copper (cuprous oxide, a red pigment)
to fit with a stock, to mount (artillery)
discs of wax impressed with the figure of a lamb and blessed at stated seasons by the Pope, used as devotional objects
aquamarine (a variety of beryl, and its colour)
a needle's worth (of thread or similar)
lower part of the vault of a furnace
awl (strong needle mainly used for leatherwork)
to mix, to bind (materials other than metals)
metal alloy, especially of gold or silver coin; also fine metal for bells
aloe (a group of plants secreting bitter juice used in medicine; may also refer to the juice itself)

alum de glace.alternateSpellings: alung de glace | alun de glace

meanings.meaning: glass alum; probably synonymous with rock alum

Alum de plume.alternateSpellings: Alum de plume | alung de plume | alum de plume

meanings.meaning: feather alum (a mineral; possibly spalt, spar, or asbestos)
a mineral, possibly the same as feather alum

Alun de glace.alternateSpellings: alum de glace | alung de glace | alum de glace

meanings.meaning: a perfuming material from the stperm whale
primer powder, powder for the touch hole
used in pharmaceutical recipes to mean "the same amount"
to feed, to lure, to bait
impostume (Cot: "An inwards swelling full of corrupt matter")

meanings.references: The author-practitioner provides a definition on fol. 112v: terre grasse appellee ardille ("fatty earth called ardille") | COT1611

meanings.meaning: Natural sand, arid or lean, in which the grains do not adhere together
billon silver (Billon refers to a mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal)
the compound of ground silver with which gilding or “silvering” is done.

In this period, “artiste” could mean skilled artisan, a Master of Arts (the university title), and was just beginning to be used in the sense of “creative artist,” as it is today. We chose to translate as “artist,” but this older connotation of artisanal skill should be kept in mind
defined on 119r as a type of sand found in Germany used for molding
ground (of a painting or for gilding)
unit of measurement, equivalent to an ell, (2–4 feet)
Autan wind (a SW or SSW wind)
sandever, glass gall, i.e., the saline dross that rises to the top of a glass melt
azure (the color, or various pigments of that color)
jewel (mostly but not necessarily a ring)
a French breed of water dog, employed for retrieving water birds in hunting
basan (sheep-skin tanned in oak- or larch-bark; distinguished from roan, which is tanned in sumach)
to batter, to mount the battery
In Ms. Fr. 640, this term refers to an impermeable layer laid down on cloth in order to paint the cloth without the paint soaking through
flashing (in metal casting: a defect produced by the metal penetrating where it should not, especially at the joint of a two-part mold)
billon (mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal)
one who makes and sells bibelots, i.e. small curios or trinkets
a poorly fortified town, fort, or place
bistre (brown pigment derived from the tarry soot of burned, resinous wood and beechwood)
grain (cereal in general, not wheat as in modern French)
Meaning uncertain. Could refer to a variety of grain or or a way of processing it.
to bolt (to pass flour, powder, or other material through a sieve)
bushel (a cylindrical vessel used for grain)
Gallicised spelling of the Lating "bolus armeni" (armenian bole)

A status conferred by the French king in the Ancien Régime, from the late medieval period onwards, granting privileges and financial aid in exchange for military manpower and taxes. "Bonne ville" thus usually referred to a city of a certain size and degree of fortification.
ring (standard part of the structure of a cannon)
ring of the mouth (“muzzle ring” in modern terminology)
ring of the breech (“base ring” in modern terminology)
ring in the middle (“trunnion ring” in modern terminology)
liquid dip used by goldsmiths to clean silver of tarnish (now often called “pickle” in English--a heated mixture of vinegar and salt)
The author-practitioner envisions this as a place of making and selling goods as well as trading knowledge
Arm defense comprising pauldron and vambrace, called a "brassart" in English in the 19th century.
brazilwood (a red wood used for dyeing)
medicinal plaster for horses, made with armenian bole
small bugloss (Anchusa arvensis, a hairy herbaceous plant of the family Boraginaceae, typically with blue flowers)
Meaning uncertain. A substance for whitening silver, probably a "pickle" for removing tarnish.
frail (a kind of basket made of rushes)
quadran (something that is square in shape)

calamine (a yellow mineral substance that looks like gold and which fire consumes but does not melt. Also the heavier soil of brass, or copper, which comes out of the sparkles and smoke that arise from the furnace and cleave to the roof and upper sides of the house, wherein it has melted)
barrel (hollow instrument, part of a furnace)
cannon-perrier (also known as a stone gun)
cape, sleeveless cloak, or woman's cap
thick paper upon which painters draw
papier-mâché, in the sense of pulped paper. See Research Essay by Tenzin Dongchung.
full charge (paper case containing shot but no powder charge which goes into the barrel)
casemate (fortified chamber, often projecting from a wall)
a pot or vessel, often used for boiling; possiby posnet as per Cotgrave (small metal pot or vessel for boiling, with a handle and three feet)
cavity, hollow (female mold or concave part of the mold that forms the relief in the molded object)
a kind of secondary mold; a cast of something which in turn will be used as a mold
ash from Acre, alkaline ash from St Jean d'Acre in the Levant used in glassmaking
calcined chalk and charcoal that crucibles are made of, and shop sweepings (dross, etc) in a goldsmith's shop
method of melting and purifying metals in ashes
blue pigment, possibly azurite ash (cf. Kirby et al., s.v. azur de cendre)
literally "camel;" a long stick on which the sword is laid down and attached in order to furbish it
watering pot (earthenware tool similar to the spout of a watering can)
helmet (the top part of an alembic)
crust (a crust-like covering or surface deposite that can appear when casting metal)
cope (the top mold in molding a bell, figurative from the ecclesiastical vestment)
coals or embers of a fire
pit coal (charbon de pierre and charbon de terre were used interchangeably at this time for the material known in English as pit coal)
meanings.references: COT1611 | Description des Art et métiers, 1776, p. 579

meanings.meaning: to overcharge, to run too violently, like a military charge
to saturate (ink), to charge (dye, possibly adding weight to the silk), to apply or cover (gilding and metalwork)
violent fire, power of fire, expulsion of fire (amount of powder in an arquebus)
grape variety from the Charentes region
to heat, to raise the temperature of an object. Can be contrasted with cuire and recuire
to give a heat (used by goldsmiths, glass-makers and iron workers)
coppersmith, tinker, or kettlemaker, depending on context
defined on 12r as fullers' earth; used in Ms. Fr. 640 for casting. According to Cotgrave, an astringent earth used in medicine
chafing dish (a vessel to hold burning charcoal or other fuel, for heating anything placed upon it, a portable grate)
unit of measure. A Parisian half-pint, according to Cot. "almost as big as our whole one"
royal cement (per Cotgrave, an excellent cement, or solder, used by goldsmiths)
modelling wax (the author-practitioner defines it as "white wax mixed with plenty of ceruse or blanc de plomb"
thread of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
vein of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
chisel or scissors when inflected in plural form
to chase (to repair the surface of a cast)
small serrated chisel (a sculptor's tool, also known as gradine or claw chisel)
cittern, an instrument of the lute family
civet, a substance taken from the glands of the civet-cat
light and clear (as opposed to heavy or dense)
a sheet of gold or gilded metal
flour glue (made of wheat flour, also known as stationer's paste)
paste glue, also known as paste, wheatpaste, or flour paste
fish glue (also known as mouth glue or water glue, since is can be moistened and made adhesive by wetting with the mouth)
hide glue (glue made from collagen-containing remains of four-footed animals, esp. the skin)
strong glue (probably made from collagen-containing remains of four-footed animals, e.g. skins, hooves etc.)
columbine (a red-violet color similar to the neck of a pigeon)
colophony (solid residue left in the distillation of resin). On 3v, defined also as pix graeca

to counterfeit (to mimic a material using a different material, e.g. counterfeit jasper made from horn; the author-practitioner distinguishes this term from imiter, which he uses to mean making a representation of a thing, e.g. a rose from horn shavings)
cupel (a small flat circular porous vessel with a shallow depression in the middle made of pounded bone ash, pressed into shape by a mold, and used in assaying gold and silver with lead)
a similarly-shaped moveable hearth of the reverberatory furnace in which silver is separated from lead cupellation
shell (i.e., a measure containing five spoonfuls)

gold ground into microscopic particles from pulverised gold leaf, ground in a mortar with honey or gum water; see guineau2014, Glossaire des matériaux de la couleur et des termes techniques employés dans les recettes de couleurs anciennes, Brepols, 2005. p. 519.
a semi-precious stone of a red hue; what it is precisely in modern terms is unclear
horn (a translucent material, most likely bovine horn in the context of Ms. Fr. 640, which grows in layers that can be split into thinner sheets)
currier (one whose trade is the dressing and colouring of leather after it is tanned)
to pour, to run through, sometimes in the sense of strain of filter
a substance to make metals flow more easily, a flux or liquefier (from French couler, "to run")
bastard culverin (gun weighing 35 quintals and armed with a 25 pounds cannonball)

copperas, protosulphates of copper, iron and zinc, distinguished as blue, green, and white copperas respectively. Etymologically it belonged properly to the copper salt, but in English use, when undistinguished by attribute or context, it has always been most commonly, and is now exclusively, applied to green copperas, the proto-sulphate of iron or ferrous sulphate, also called green vitriol, used in dyeing, tanning, and making ink
toadstone (petrified tooth of the earless seal, originally thought to come from the head of the toad; it was used as a precious stone, and to detect the presence of poison)
filth (possibly the scale resulting from excessive heat when melting metal)
crystal glass (similar to that made in Murano)
crocus of iron, made by dissolving iron filings in nitric acid or vinegar; used in Ms. Fr. 640 as an additive to mold materials to make the mold stronger and retain heat
meaning uncertain, possibly a slip of the pen or corruption of crayons
cuirass (a defense for the torso, consisting of breastplate and backplate)
to cook (transform by the action of heat)
to damask (to apply to a cloth patterns in the style of damask)
to decrepitate (to calcine or roast a salt or mineral until it no longer crackles in the fire)
to rid of grease or impurities; to degrease, or make lean or clean (as fullers do in fulling cloth)
to macerate, allay, or soften, by steeping; also to thin
demi-culverin (gun weighing 30 quintals and armed with a 20 pounds cannonball)
unit of currency (1/12 of a sol, 1/240 of a livre)
unit of weight (1/785 of a kilogram)
wares (from denerée ware which has the value of a denier)
tooth (wolf or dog tooth, used as a tool for burnishing gold and silver)
to lay tree roots bare in the winter; to take off shoes
a grinding tool that works on a wheel to polish the inside of pewter dishes and bowls (perhaps a lathe like tool)
to release (i.e., the mold releasing the cast)
design NB THIS IS TRANS AS "DRAWING" ON 62r, and design on 131r

to temper (i.e., acc. to OED2008, to bring (anything) to a proper or suitable condition, state, or quality, by mingling with something else; to qualify, alloy, or dilute by such mixture or combination. To mix, mingle, blend (ingredients) together, or (one ingredient) with another, in proper proportions. Based on a perception that balance for the proper state of a material or human body should ideally be achieved.

to distemper (painting technique that involves a variety of binding media such as egg, glue, size; not to confuse with modern tempera, which refers more narrowly to a technique using egg yolk as the binding medium)
at discretion, as much as is needed
a jewel made of two pieces joined together
measurement unit, a hands breadth, or the breadth of four fingers
drug, any substance used as an ingredient in various making processes

rock water (the author-practitioner defines this term on 11r: eau de roche, qu’ilz appellent, c’est une eau distillée des mines où l’azur ou vert d’azur se trouve, qui naturellement distille par les veines de la montaigne ou qui est par alambic distillée par des pierres mineralles d’azur ou cuivre – "it is a water distilled from mines where azure or vert d'azur is found, which distills naturally through the veins of the mountain or is distilled through an alembic from mineral stones of azure or copper.")

Eau de vie.alternateSpellings: eau de vye | eau de viye

meanings.meaning: eau-de-vie, i.e., distilled wine, such as brandy, or spirits
water in which bread has been boiled
electrum (an alloy of gold and silver thought to have occult properties, such as protection from poison)
meanings.references: OED2008 | Heinrich Khunrath's 1597 manuscript, Consilium de Vulcani magia fabrecatione armorum Achilles_ (Ms. Rål 4, 1597 (43), National Library of Sweden

meanings.meaning: to imbibe (to be absorbed, soak in)
to imbibe (to be absorbed, soak in)
to helve (set on a haft or handle)
a measurment equivalent to a handspan, c. 25cm
to slot (something into a groove or notch)
the space between or middle part
scale, especially in metal working. The scales that form as a blacksmith hammers iron, which fall to the floor of the forge, and are used in diverse processes

scarlet (in both French and English, this was usually a rich red color but could refer to other colors. Could also refer to cloth of this color, usually of a very high quality, and worn ceremonially by high-ranking officials)
hammering process aimed at making metals harder and denser. Often translated in English as "hammer-hardening"
quillon block (part of the hilt of a sword)
escutcheon (shield or lozenge shape, especially a mark on a cannon which may indicate the powder charge)
hanter en escusson = shield grafting (a method of grafting trees)
to scratch (creating a pattern in satin by a technique akin to pinking)
a blue pigment, possibly smalt, azurite, or verditer
gules red enamel (an opaque red enamel; cf. transparent rouge clair enamel)
emery (hard stone used in powder form for polishing)
meanings.references: OED2008 | browne1672  The Magnet attracteth..the Smyris or Emery in powder

meanings.meaning: spinet (small keyboard instrument with plucked strings)
to wipe, to dry, to cleanse
looking-glass tin (tin alloy used for backing glass mirrors)
tammy cloth (used for straining or sieving)
tow (fiber of flax, hemp, or jute, prepared for spinning by some process of scutching)
breach (made by an explosive, e.g. a petard)
falconet (according to the author-practitioner, a cannon 10 pans long weighing four quintals, with shot weighing 1.25 lb, and a powder charge of half a lb)
to baste (i.e. to sew on loosely)
meaning uncertain, possibly a kind of wool cloth known as "wadnall" in contemporary English
closure (the closing part of a clay contour)
figure (where clearly referring to a material object)
figurated (decorated with human or animal figures as opposed to abstract ornaments)
thread of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
vein of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
fine (in the case of metals, this can mean pure; in other cases it is often unclear whether it refers to quality or purity)
flower (the whole plant or the bloom)
Meaning uncertain, possibly "a thunder-stone, a kind of stone wherewith Cutlers furbish their blades” (Cotgrave)
Florey (Indigo pigment from the dark blue foam and scum on the surface of the woad or indigo dyeing vat)
violent fire (fire that is blown up into live flames)
violent fire (which is blown up into live flames. "En termes de Chymie, on appelle feu de chasse, un feu violent, quand on a ouvert tous les registres d’un fourneau." Delaulne 1721)
founding (the process, e.g. of founding a cannon)
borer (a boring tool larger than a gimlet)
a very hot furnace, or kiln

meanings.references: (four and fourneau seem to be used interchangeably)

meanings.meaning: reverberatory furnace (using reflected heat, with the fire separated from the hearth; the chamber can reach very high temperatures without the material catching fire)
furnace fanned by the wind, as opposed to a four a souflets (bellows furnace)
furbisher (sword-cutler, one who assembles and furbishes swords)

meanings.references: (four and fourneau seem to be used interchangeably)

meanings.meaning: possibly barbers' oven (used for heating towels)
fresil (on 94v, the author-practitioner defines this as ceste escaille de fer tombant a la forge des mareschaulx "the iron scale falling at the farriers' forge")
fusion, i.e., melting of glass or metal at very high heat
a tool for furbishing (i.e., polishing and removing rust from sword blades)
fustet (a subspecies of sumac tree whose yellowish wood is used for medicines and dyes)
gabion (a large basket-like container filled with rocks and used as protection for gunners)
galipot, or the turpentine or resin which exudes from, and hardens upon, the stem of certain pines. Not to be confused with the English “gallipot”—a vessel used in alchemy)
madder (plant source of a red dye and pigment)
gate (in casting, the opening in the mold into which the molten metal is poured)
jet (a hard black variety of coal that takes a brilliant polish and is used for jewellery, ornaments, etc.)
to glaze (with oil paint, to achieve a glassy surface)
egg glair (egg white, often beaten with water and strained, used as a pigment binder)
a vessel; according to Cotgrave, an earthenware bowl, cup, or jub
gum ammoniac (also known as “ammoniac gum” or ammoniacum. A complex gum/oil/resin mixture obtained from the stems of carrot family plant, dorema ammoniacum, native to Iran and India)
tragacanth gum (a natural gum obtained from the dried sap of several species of Middle Eastern legumes of the genus Astragalus)
Meaning uncertain, possibly lower quality gum (gomme + -iche, suffix for lower quality)

great metals (unclear which metals this refers to:  on fol. 32v, the author-practitioner lists gold, silver, copper, latten, and iron, but on fol. 134v writes of the casting of gold, and on fol. 156r, of lead “and the other great metals").
fatty (soft, malleable, or rich, according to material or context)
scratch-brush (either a large wire brush or a small, pencil-shaped brush now commonly used in clockmaking)
a particular type of potters' clay or earth for making stoneware vessels, or the stoneware vessels themselves

Meaning uncertain, probably a smaller type of ingot than the saumon, and more convenient to sell. See eg. Dictionnaire universel de Commerce, which likens grile to saumon, although to the author practionner these are clearly different (on fol. 28v)
to grip, to stick, to take hold
name given to several species of squirrel and, by extension, to their fur
a grey pigment, probably made from blacksmiths' iron scale
coarse, thick, large (of sand, cloth etc.)

large wares (grosserie in this period often also referred to work done in bulk (see Littré), but this is not what seems to be implied in the ms. See also Cennini's use of grosseria as opposed to minuteria, suggesting large wares as opposed to small delicate ones. Cennini’s translator Ashbee: “metal work of the larger sort, as opposed to minuteria. Our term, hammered hollow ware, would partly express it. It mainly included the beating of large vessels into shapes, but it did not exclude the processes of casting.”)

guede woad (as distinct from pastel or "pastel woad"; it is unclear whether the author means the two terms to be entirely synonymous. Cotgrave: “Many of the French dyers call the courser sort of stuffe Guesde, and the finer Pastel; most writers confound them.”
muzzle (of a gun, to distinguish from bouche)

pig (in metalwork, a large ingot of iron cast straight from the blast furnace. In English, the term "pig" is still widely used and includes iron and nonferrous materials cast into sand or metal moulds provided that it is intended for remelting before use. In French "gueuse" is restricted to virgin iron.)
gimlet (a small tool with a screw point, grooved shank, and cross handle for boring holes)
alidade (pivoted sight or pointer, typically part of an astrolabe)
hackbut (used interchangeably with "arquebus" in the period. Cotgrave also has “caliver”, which is a small smooth-bore long firearm)
arquebus à croc, or wall gun (a gun with a hook preventing the recoil by steadying it on a wall or battlement)
haqueton (a now obsolete English term designating a jerkin or plated leather jacket)
Meaning uncertain, perhaps or strong-box or coffer. On 163r, it refers to a specific quantity of amber, possibly a coffer's worth
meanings.references: DMF2015 | DMLBS (Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources) | Ducange

meanings.meaning: Ben oil (derived from the Moringa tree)
oil of sulfur (vitriol or sulfuric acid)
keep Fr. — [has this been looked into?] Defined in 137r
impalpable (used in casting as a technical term for a powder ground so fine that no grit can be sensed when rubbing it between the fingers)
imprimatura, i.e., OED: :a thin priming or ground, frequently coloured, applied to an artist's canvas or panel" (painting)
a shade of red (Cot: "a deep, rich, or bright carnation")

a literary word, essentially meaning ‘dishonourableness’. Similar word ‘honorificabilitudinitatibus’ used in Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost (Act V, Scene I) and many other sources. Also found in Dictionaries from the late 15th/16thC. Although the trick is in Jean Prevost (54v-56v), he does not use this term.
injection (not necessarily intravenous injection, but any administration of liquid medicine into any part of the body, e.g. enemas etc)

meanings.references: corneille1694 "Pierre pretieuse, qui par son feu semble tenir du rubis. Elle en differe pourtant en ce que sa couleur est moins chargée; elle ressemble aussi à l’Amethyste, tirant quelque peu sur le violet. (...) Toutes ces sortes de Pierres sont Orientales, apportées de Cananor, Calecut ou Cambaïe."

meanings.meaning: Floral Games, a poetry competition in Renaissance Toulouse, in which lifecast flowers were given as prizes
double handful (the amount that can be cupped in two hands)
a natural day (24 hours). In contrast to a jour artificiel (a tradesman’s day from sunrise to sunset), or jour civil (also 24 hours, but starting according to the custom of the place or nation)
Having perforations or holes, pierced; spec. designating an ornamental openwork pattern

Meaning uncertain; "vieulx K" occurs twice in the manuscript (fol. 86v and 147v), and both instances are associated with a silver-copper alloy. Silver-copper alloy was used in minting coins, where it was known as billon. The abbreviation K might thus indicate a coin, perhaps the German Kreuzer which was abbreviated K and was made of silver-copper alloy up until the seventeenth century.

latten (a copper alloy, containing tin, zinc, and sometimes lead).  While often assumed to be identical to "brass" today, in early modern Europe the precise composition of the copper alloys, such as laiton, latten, brass, and bronze, was not fixed, nor was latten necessarily considered an alloy separate from (or inferior to) bronze
potin latten (presumably latten made with potin, an alloy of copper and tin, usually with lead and zinc, used by ancient Celtic peoples for making coins)
plate (of metal. In plated armor, overlapping plates or bands connected by rivets or internal leathers to achieve articulation)
sheet (of metal, thinner and/or smaller than a lame or "plate")
(tool used to charge guns or the equivalent measure of powder)
lake (pigment produced by a lake process; usually a red one. From lac, a red colorant made from a variety of organic materials)
dried lake pigment, formed into a flat shape for storage and sale
dried lake pigment, shaped into round beads for storage and sale
a form of lead ingots that the Germans use, as opposed to the French saulmon
to wash (for pigments, this refers to a process now known as levigation)
residue (of gold or silver, recovered from ashes, sweepings, and crucibles in a goldsmith's workshop)
female lizard; usually qualified as being small
bundle (a quantity of glass for sale)

meanings.references: PHS: I THINK MOLDS ARE BOUND TOGETHER WITH WIRE, NOT TIED. LIER IS THE VERB USED

meanings.meaning: line (often a measurement; Cotgrave says a twelfth of an inch; in the ms on fol. 22r it is defined as a twelfth of a king's foot)
roll or strip of fabric, band
livre (any of a number of coins or units of account used in France)
loop (mass of raw iron from the smelting furnace, also called "bloom")
lute (clay or cement composed of various ingredients, and used to stop a hole, coat vessels to protect them from the fire or seal a joint between pieces of apparatus e.g. for distillation)
to lute (cover the outside of the vessel with lute to seal and protect the vessel from the heat)
liquid binder used in sand molding
marble, "sur le marbre" used to mean "on the marble slab," e.g., of grinding

marcasite (bronze-yellow mineral consisting of iron disulphide, also known as pyrite. Bernard Palissy (c. 1510-c.1590) defines marcasites as imperfect metals, sometimes formed in a square fashion, like dice)
Meaning uncertain, could refer to the "cascabel", the projection behind the breech of a muzzle-loading cannon
a yellow pigment ( the word "massicot" today refers to a pale yellow lead monoxide; in earlier times it could refer to lead-tin oxide)

possibly a wild peach, Prunus persica var. persica Batsch. Peaches in general are called pesches in Fr. 640. This is a big yellow peach also known as “Pavie” in mod. Fr. Often just called peach in English today (vs "melicotony" in the 18th c.)
a specific variety of copper alloy, in Ms. Fr. 640, used in bells and petards, among other works
Meaning uncertain. It seems to refer to an additive which makes tin look like silver

great metals (unclear which metals this refers to:  on fol. 32v, the author-practitioner lists gold, silver, copper, latten, and iron, but on fol. 134v writes of the casting of gold, and on fol. 156r, of lead “and the other great metals").
bread pith (the inner part of a loaf)
millet (a variety of common barley, of which a very coarse bread is made, especially in the South of France)
measure of grain and dry goods between 110-120 English pounds or half a setier
mine, source, quarry, or cave dug in the ground
debris (in particular of brass and copper)
the grindings from sharpening (powder made up of stone and metal particles left over from sharpening metal tools on a whetstone)
pincers (i.e. a pair of pincers used as a tool)

Meaning uncertain, but likely a "moresque" ornament, imitating Ottoman fabrics. By itself, the word is used for forms found in ornament and decoration in the applied arts in Europe. In early seventeenth-century English, it could more specifically mean a grotesque ornament.
morion (open-faced helmet with cheek pieces and a brim, either with a comb or a point on top)
mortar (grinding tool, as in mortar and pestle)

petard (artillery. Note that mortier and the English “mortar” refer to an artillery piece which fires at high angles; but the author-practitioners also uses mortier for a bomb which in English was known as a petard)

a type of sand used for molding that is the byproduct of sharpening knives and scissors, as described on fol. 71v; it occurs twice on fol. 73r, where the scribe has left it blank and the author-practitioner has filled in the word
to die (for colors, in the sense of fading away); to die down (of a fire)

musket (musket also means sparrohawk, a small bird of prey, deriving from the French. The name was probably first given to small artillery pieces (see e.g. falcon) before it came to denote a hand-held long-barelled firearm)
to shed (of an animal with fur)
muid, i.e., a large vessel or measure
nature, the natural, natural disposition, innate property or quality
niello (decorations on silver in a black enamel made of lead, copper, silver, and ammonia salt )
Meaning uncertain, likely a black pigment; in Fr. 640, it seems to be specific to painting on glass
a black pigment, possibly made from hammer scale, known as scales black in English.
peach black (black pigment made by charring peach stones and grinding the product. Percarum Lapidum refers to the prepared peach stones)
unidentified black pigment, possibly based on pit coal
walnut (often used as an approximate measure for an amount of material "the size of a walnut")

noyau is used in Ms. Fr. 640 to mean “core,” that is, the inner block in a mold that allows casting a figure with a hollow core or center. Another name for such a “core” in French is âme. Félibien and Cellini use the two terms interchangeably (anima and nocciolo in Italian). The author-practitioner uses “ame” once on fol. 124r to mean core, but he seems to be contrasting it to the “noyau” by which he seems to mean the outer plaster mold. He contrasts molding and casting “en chassis” with that done “en noyau,” meaning molding with plaster either in one-piece or multi-piece molds
young bud of a tree (in grafting)
to annoint, in the sense of greasing of smearing with an unguent
a type of chisel, for fine engraving or chasing
tinsel (leaf metal imitating some more precious material; in Fr. 640, brass or copper leaf imitating gold)
gold color (sometimes meaning a gold color produced by a particular process)
spangle gold (a type of gold which could be found by panning around Toulouse)
pistolet gold, coin worth half a pistole
mordant gilding; see Research Essay by Njeri Ndungu.
amalgam gilding, mercury mixed with ground gold to a paste, painted onto metal, then mercury is burned off, leaving the gold melded to the metal
someone who works with precious metals in general
orgue (assembly of several gun barrels mounted on a rack)
elm (tree whose roots boiled in wine produce a binding medium known as Magistra)
orpiment (bright yellow pigment made from arsenic trisulfide, also known as orpin)
a small plank (in Fr. 640, often of wood)

meanings.references: Intermédiaire des chercheurs et des curieux, 30.08.1901, col. 309

meanings.meaning: Meaning uncertain, likely refers to a plant with palmately lobed leaves, perhaps cut-leaved dead-nettle, Lamium hybridum or the castor oil plant, Ricinus communis.
Possibly a medicine, made of pig's tallow and palmately lobed leaves. Used as an additive to enhance the drying capacities of oil.
handspan (the distance between the ends of thumb and little finger; a measuring unit in the South of France; approx. 25cm)
unit of measure for the sale of plate glass, which sells at 10 or 12 livres
thick paper used for making cards, but also rough paper used to wrap merchandise

pappus (modified calyx, the part of an individual floret that surrounds the base of the corolla tube in flower heads of the plant family Asteraceae); in Fr. 640, suggested, along with dandelion, as a particularly difficult test of life-casting ability (124r).
fuller (a profession employed in finishing cloth using fine clay)
to fumigate, when dealing with molds and metals
akin to; or to be kin to or related to in nature
to pass (in heating iron and steel, this can mean heating the metal to cause them to pass from one color to another)
small type of cannon, also called base

pastel woad (the author-practitioner distinguishes pastel from guesde. Cotgrave calls it “Dyers woad (of a finer sort then that which is called Guesde),” and in the entry for Guesde, Cotgrave comments that “most writers confound them”)
Caltha palustris, a variety of buttercup (ranunculus family)
a kind of peach native to the Gers
hanger of a scabbard, attaching it to the belt, also known as frogs
to penetrate, to reach all the smaller parts of the mold
dead arsemart, dead culerage, ciderage, peachwort (seems to refer to a running agent or a kind of flux added to liquify or clean metal)
peck, a measure of about 5 pints, used to measure oats
pleasure pieces (guns not intended to be put on carriages)
a king's foot, a standard 12 inch foot unit of measure
magnet (in modern chemical nomenclature, siderite is iron carbonate, also called chalybite)
paintbrush (not to be confused with brosse, which can be a flat brush)
pint (French or Parisian pint as a measure of volume; or a vessel containing that measure)
pistolet, a gold coin, often the Spanish (double-)escudo
a specific type of plane called a draw knife, described on fol. 95v
a tool for burnishing tin plates, described on fol. 30v
to plant, or to arrange or set, such as of arranging animals for lifecasting on a slab of clay
slab of earth clay, on which animals being arranged for lifecasting are set
thin piece of metal or wood
slab, in Fr. 640, used for preparing for lifecasting
in clockmaking, this refers to a device for scoring cogs evenly (on fol. 82r)
Dutch quill (a quill that has been heated in sand or before the fire in order to harden it)
to smooth with pumice, to polish
to pounce, to transfer a design by pricking a pattern with a pin and marking through the pricked holes with charcoal or chalk or similar

defined by the author-practitioner on fol. 94r in the context of sword construction as an "iron strip which closes off the branch which is at the end of the ricasso to stop thrusts from sliding into the guard"
porphyry, in Fr. 640, often referring to the porphyry slab used for grinding on
cutting-punch, a tool for punching and cutting out pieces of metal plate
pipe that directs the air from the bellows through the tuelle and up into the furnace
to draw, to portray, to depict
putty (meaning either a powder or a paste)
an alloy of copper and tin, usually with lead and zinc, formerly used in the manufacture of coins
a large mushroom that often grows overnight
an alchemical projection powder, or the philosophers' stone; a term of derision because so much gold was wasted in the searching for it. Thence also, any cousening or iugling powder
thumb, a unit of measure not to be confused with an inch
horsetail reed, used for polishing and sanding, e.g., of gessoed panels
to prick, leaving a mark on marble with a knife
to set (of plaster, cement, and the like)
to give a good hold, used in Fr. 640 to describe the consistency of sand used for frame casting
fine powder used for priming a gun
aurum musivum, aurum mosaicum, mosaic gold (a mixture of tin, sulfur, mercury and sal ammoniac)
type of well operated with one or more wheels

a term designating several measurements; according to Cotgrave,  "a quarter of a pound; also, a quarterne (or the fourth part) of a hundreth; also, a Pinte, or little Quart; also, the halfe of an Emine; also, a Quarter of the Moone. (En Languedoc le Quarteron, common & pour le bled, & pour la terre qui le produit, contient 4 Civadiers, dits aussi boisseuxm divisez par demiz.)"
tail (of an animal or a sword)
pomace, the grape skins, stems, etc. left over after pressing
realgar (an arsenal sulphide mineral, also known as ruby sulphur, or ruby of arsenic); used as a yellow pigment

to tranform again by the action of heat. In f.111r, the author defines "recuire" as the process of turning a mold red for the second time (“Faire pour la seconde fois rougir”). He contrasts this process to drying (“desseicher”) metals. Similarly, on a margin note of f.118v, “recuire” is defined as “turning a frame red,” a process similar to what “is done for gold and silver.”

to anneal (a specific heating treatment which craftsmen use in order to “perfect their craft” or “make it more durable.” Goldsmiths, for example, restitute the desired malleability and ductility of their objects by reheating or annealing them. Glassblowers use a special furnace to reheat the glass to prevent it from shattering. This process is known as “annealing” or “tempering” in English. See Ashbee’s translations of “ricuocere” in Benevenuto Cellini’s Two Treatises)
regulus (piece of metal separated from a mineral or ore by smelting or reduction, as the first stage of purification)

meanings.references: Kreidel and Niedner, Technologisches Wörterbuch in deutscher, französischer und englischer Sprache (1855).

meanings.meaning: to repair the surface of a cast
to retrace (to follow an existing line with another medium)
to take away or remove something from something else
rocaille (in Ms. Fr. 640, this refers to small glass beads which may or may not be colored)
to moisten, to wet, or to sprinkle with dew. Singular instance on 161v
Meaning uncertain, likely a pink pigment made with materials thought to have come from Alexandria; perhaps Alexandrine ruby found on the banks of the Nile
a method of enamelling red glass on gold
red in body (probably in the sense of opaque red)
sand (powders of various sorts used to make molds in sand casting). In Fr. 640, also used to denote plaster casting
sand bank or sand gravel, type of geological formation where one finds a deposit or concentration of gravel and sand usually due to erosion
cobalt oxide of a blue color sometimes used for making cobalt glass, a blue sapphire glass that was ground to make smalt, used as a pigment
sandarac (a hard resin from a conifer tree in Algeria, used in varnish production and pharmacy)
dragon's blood (juice from the dragon tree, also the herb called bloodwort)
sanguine, earth pigment of a hue ranging from brown to red
to close, to hold (e.g. sand encasing a flower)
sausage (in Ms. Fr. 640, it is used to describe a cloth tube with powder, acting as a fuse for a petard)
large ingot or mass of raw, unprocessed metal straight from the furnace
sap of trees; "en sape" when the sap is rising
small bristle brush, used by goldsmiths; not to be confused with the fabric or garnment of the same name
scribe (in Ms. Fr. 640, it seems to refer to letter-painters, sign-painters, or more generally mediocre painters)
stil de grain yellow (pigment made from the sap of weld and chalk, from the German schüttgrün)
white salt, uncertain whether of a particular kind. Perhaps for "sol blanc," sol blanc," a white, calcareous earth mined particularly in Saxony
An unidentified salt, called de armonic by the English according to the author-practitioner
likely refers to the scum taken off the top of vitreous matter before it vitrifies
vessel used to carry the wine harvest
fenugreek (popular name for the plant also known in French as fenugrec)
a measure for diverse things, and therefore of diverse sizes; physicians used the smallest, 3 ounces
gold (literally "sun," the alchemical symbol for gold)
currency unit, 12 deniers and 1/20 of a livre. Abbreviated "s."
sole (base or floor of a furnace)
to become porous, to fill with bubbles (in the context of casting, for example, when gases are mixed in and make the cast porous and brittle)
natural sulfur, also known as virgin sulfur
Literally "breathing hole;" in Fr. 640, a vent (in molds for casting)
tang (spike-shape extension at the end of a sword blade by which it is fixed to the hilt)
white powder, perhaps feldspar, a chalk-like deposit, zinc, or a zinc alloy; possibly synonymous with spat, described in Fr. 640 as found in Germany, near Augsburg
an earth used for frame-casting (described by the author-practitioner on fol. 108r, possibly synonymous with spalt
stavesacre (plant whose seeds are used against lice and mange)
a kind of granular limestone, or tufa
sublimate (material that has been sublimed, i.e. heated into a vapor, then condensed or precipitated)
to grind finely, or to make thinner
suffocation of the matrix (medical term used to designate female hysteria)
sandever (also called "glass gall," per Cot: "the fattie substance floating on glasse when it is red-hot in the furnace, and which being cold is as hard as stone, yet brittle, and easily broken")
slab of glass for crushing colors
panel, a painting on wood and usually not on canvas
taffer (a pigment usually obtained by roasting cobalt glance, white sand, or quartz; used in porcelain painting, and in enameling pottery, to produce a blue color)
talc or talcum, a green-to-gray, soft mineral, hydrous magnesium silicate
to taper, to make tapering, of a wall
to sieve (for dry ingredients and to strain for wet ingredients)
tellin, any marine bivalve mollusk of the genus Tellina
boulbène earth (usually found in the Garonne valley and essentially made of clay and sand)
founder's earth (mostly used by bell founders, and made of reclaimed material from used molds, such as sand, clay, manure, hair, and brick dust)
umber (yellow brown pigment containing iron oxide, earth from Umbria)
fullers' earth (a fine clay used in finishing cloth)
presumably a specific shape or kind of dish
theriac (a medicine made by mixing several ingredients such as plants or animal parts)

to imitate (to make a visual representat.headWord: to imitate (to make a visual representation of a thing, e.g. a rose from horn shavings; the author-practitioner distinguishes this term from contrefaire which he uses to mean mimicking a material using a different material, e.g. counterfeit jasper made from horn)

meanings.meaning: to imitate (the author-practitioner apparently distinguishes between imiter and contrefaire, with imiter meaning to make a representation of something (a thing or scene), and contrefaire to mimic a (valuable) material in (more available) materials, such as coral contrefaict and jaspe contrefaict

toadstone (petrified tooth of the earles.headWord: toadstone (petrified tooth of the earless seal, originally thought to come from the head of the toad; it was used as a precious stone, and to detect the presence of poison)

meanings.meaning: cake (a firmly pressed ball or slab)
An inner verrill; the round plate of iron whereby a piece of wood, often turned on, is preserved from wearing, and burning
cake (a firmly pressed ball or slab)
crosswise, used to qualify molding and casting. Seems to refer to a technique of orienting the gate in a mold, characteristic of metalworkers in Foix
word with many meanings, from bird cage to small scale used to weight coins
tempering (the process of quenching a heated metal in a liquid)
tempering bath (the liquid used for quenching)
to temper (metals), to quench (as part of the tempering process)
tempering process for hardening metal of tools, e.g. files
triblet (a disc on which goldsmiths set rings or other round objects to file or work them)
tripoli (silica stone, the powder of which is used to polish metals and glass)
blast-pipe (the conduit at the bottom of the furnace or kiln, through which the bellows’ pipes are inserted)
tutty, a medicinal stone or dust made of crude zinc oxyde
quill or pipe, in the sense of a ferule
to buff enamel with fine sand
vapor (refers to a method of blowing into a mold to remove ashes but the DMF2015 describes vapeur as either dry or humid and the recipe is unclear)
to ventilate, to free from chaff by winnowing
probably “verdigris” as it used in a context of casting potin
a color (likely a green mineral chalk)
rod, or with guns, a ramrod
a rod that painters rest their hand upon when they paint, in the sense of maulstick
a technique of enameling on a metal ground

glassmaker (in the Parisian context, a profession which produces glass objects, as contrasted with another group of glassworkers, the “vitriers,” who made flat plate glass and stained glass windows and did painting on glass, for stained glass)
green verditer, an artificial basic copper carbonate
strap hinge (the word is found in 18th-c. documents from lower Poitou/Charente)
a blister or bubble (Used on fol. 36v in connection with blowing glass). According to Cot, vessie can also mean a distilling vessel
wimble, A boring tool similar to a gimlet
gimlet, possibly an alternative Occitan name for the tool that the author usually calls guimbelet

a species of willow (often salix viminalis), employed for basket making, wicker, and thatch, among other uses. It is Occitan word for the French osier, cultivated along the Garonne. Sometimes called “withy” or “osier” in English.

glassworker, the profession that makes plate glass, stained glass windows, and paints on glass.  In the Parisian context, the vitriers apparently engaged in a different range of glassworking than the verriers, who were first recognized in 1583 in the Statutes of Paris
oil of sulfur (vitriol or sulfuric acid)
common, on f.100r refers to an artisan who does things in a simpler way or lacks the appropriate tools
